review_title: Great benefits and decent pay;  Leadership lacks integrity

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Menlo Park, CA

Unconscious Bias (CRT) training is also mandatory. Training for new Admins and the understanding of the work Admins do is greatly needed. This position can be stressful for some based on the workload.

job_title: Inpatient Pharmacy Technician II in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Competitive pay and benefits, night shift differential. Parking for evening shift. New equipment and tools.
cons:
Not flexible with scheduling, shift swaps, or coverage.
Training is not optimized with trainers often being chosen at random, or whoever is scheduled that day.
Trainers being forced to sign off competency documents for trainees even if they dont feel like they are ready.
Even though they will deny, retaliation has been happening with employees that speak up.
Unable to trust supervisors and management, as it doesn't seem like they have our backs and are often dishonest.
They do not listen to feedback from employees, and try to implement policies without having knowledge of current work flow and conditions.
Not everyone has the same opportunities for training in new areas.

job_title: Finance in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Easy to stand behind mission of women's and children's health
cons:
Specific to the Finance depart only, I will share what I wished others would have shared with me before joining.
1. The work relationship between you and your Admin Directors, VP, and CFO will be one way. Your career and growth will not be their concern, not even slightly.
2. It is rare if you do have a manager or director who cares for your growth. If you do, they are aware of their need to leave as they themselves are NOT supported.
3. Self serving and distrustful leadership. Words should be taken lightly.
4. Difficult environment to be vulnerable or to find trust. A cycle of mistrust.
5. High turnover leads to more work absorbed by remaining staff, and staying, without incentive.
6. Elevated are those who befriend the right staff.
7. Discrimination against those with thick accents.
8. Pay in Finance is lower than area hospitals and tech industry.
9. Cold culture and hard to feel valued, overperformer or not.

I hope this helps those who are looking to join the team. Although I would like nothing more than for someone great to come on board and possibly change the environment, it is more depressing to see them realize after a few months that they made the wrong decision. Go where your skills will be valued and appreciated, instead!

review_title: A challenging career path gone downhill
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Great on your resume
Fast paced working environment
Competitive pay
cons:
What once was a great career path with plenty of motivation and ways to improve my work ethic has gone downhill since management has changed.  What was a calm and managed working environment has gone into a hostile workplace. 
One of the cons are with taking personal time off. In the past employees were able to take time off in a timely manner. There are some days where your time off may be denied which was completely fine however taking time off appears to be a dime a dozen. Favoritism comes a factor when it comes to taking time off since management has their favorites and their non favorite employees.  There are a few employees who are having their time off approved consistently while the rest of the technicians struggle on making switches with others to ensure there is proper coverage. Talk about being fair right?
Another con is with working together. Throughout my career, employees were working together however it appears there is a lot of finger pointing and no resolutions to problems that occur on a daily basis.  On some occasions I have witnessed new management yelling to a few employees in front of other techs instead of being professional, putting employees aside and speaking into a calm manner. In the future I hope upper management will look into these issues and find resolutions to these fixes.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: This hospital runs like a bussiness, not your typical inefficient hosptial. Perfection is their goal.
cons:
Union, union, union: There is no incentive to working really hard, if there is no reward. Everyone is treated equally regardless of talent. The union prevents movement of registered nurses without masters degress into advaced practice roles. Some may agrue that that is beneficial to the hospital, but it leaves no room for rewarding thoose who work the hardest. 

More importantly, the nurses who have been in the hospital for a few years have it made. The union allows seniority nurses to chose their shifts and vacations. This means that half of the nurses are getting exactly what they want and the newer nurses are not getting any compromise. This applies to scheduling, requested days-off, what shift they can work, etc. Take for example that there is no flexability when it come to swithcing someome off of night shift, even if their is medical reasoning.

Bullying from both nursing staff, nursing management, ancillary staff observed and reported to management and HR but several bullying recipients report no change in treatment by bullies. Management appears to passively allow this as a form of staff control. Some staff units are very cliquish-a high school type atmosphere.

job_title: Middle Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The hospital attracts and hires top-notch talent.  Working in a renowned research facility is great and the atmosphere is intellectually challenging.  Salaries are very fair and benefits are excellent.
cons: But being in a management role at LPCH is hard.  Managers are held accountable for improving engagement scores, quality management systems, etc., but there are many processes and procedures that are very time consuming, cumbersome, or just plain don't work. Managers must spend too much of their expensive time trying to get simple things done.  There is a big emphasis on process improvement in the clinical areas, but no one is looking at the HR systems, purchasing procedures, etc. -- the smaller things that waste a lot of time.

job_title: Manager of Communications, Packard II 0 in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great mission. The location is beautiful. It was my only solace while working there. Nice amenities for employees. The Stanford affiliation carries with it a good reputation.
cons: Wow, I've never experienced such an disorganized work environment. When I arrived I was told that my position was now completely different to what I interviewed for. I was also told In my interview and subsequent offer that I would have duel reporting between communications and  Packers 2.0. As a communications professional it was important to have corporate communication's influence in my work to ensure messaging and branding were consistent. I was tasked with putting together a communications plan due within two weeks of my arrival but was not allowed to speak with people. I was  housed in Marcom off campus. There was no on boarding. I found out that a brochure had been developed on the project I was working on weeks after my arrival. The environment was hostile.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Very good benefits, PTO accrued quickly, system easy to learn, quality equipment, clean new hospital
cons: Parking sucks, have to walk or shuttle 15 min to work. If you have a mid shift, very difficult to find parking, as lot will be full. No discount whatsoever.  Sick calls are frequent and nothing done about it. Mostly the same people always calling out. We have a lot of PTO but hard to get time off. Some employees are not motivated and only do bare minimum, sometimes less than that. It demotivates some who feel they are picking up the slack of others.

review_title: Great place to start, but a dead-end for the experienced

review_title: Physicians and hospital clerks are easy to work with.

cons: The number one challenges that I had encounter working for Lucile Packard Children Hospital when the Revenue Management hired a Manager that do not have enough experience regarding coding and billing. Complexity of coding and billing for surgery that have contradiction of interpretation of operative report and patient diagnosis.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The patients was very nice! The environment is safe and clean.
cons: The Nurses where not nice ! Employees  who enjoy making your life miserable. Nurses eat their young at Lucile Packard!I will never forget my experience working there! They smile in your face while stabbing you in the back! I will never forget that one nurse who was always harassing me ! She would run to the office behind my back and tell lies. It's not diverse less than 1% of African American working there. It's a high turnover place lots of travelers and new grads!Expensive parking for employees. Food is pricey so carry your lunch. If they don't like you for any reason they will do everything to get rid of you! Leadership don't listen! Assistant Nurse managers need more classes on leadership roles! I would rather work at UCSF children's!

job_title: Analyst II in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I am sure they are treating people very well, on average.!
cons: HR just informed us that LPCH can terminate new employees as stated in trial period verbiage without due process - new employees are not eligible for any verbal or written notice. There is enough air cover in the LPCH HR policy that a manager can fire you at will during trial period whether there is any performance issue or not. Also employees in trial period are not eligible for any FMLA related absences. They may not provide information about trial period during the offer. It will left to you to actively ask for it, read it and understand it. Use this as a warning and do your own due diligence.

job_title: Critical Care RN in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The work culture is amazing.  The people are great and management in every department are always very helpful.  They go through a great deal to retain employees.  The retirement is some of the best in the Bay Area at 10%  after the first year 5% given then 5% match.  And the pay is the best I've made in my career
cons: the food in the cafeteria is overpriced and needs more flavor

review_title: I use to love waking up knowing that at LPCH I was making a difference.
job_title: White Collar in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Working with some of the best healthcare providers in a fast pace environment both challenges you as well as rewarding you with the knowledge you do make a difference
cons: Management has changed.  Rather than family, it seems it is more business than caring.

review_title: Quality organization for experience but not a long term option
job_title: Financial Analyst in Menlo Park, CA
pros:
Large organization with the resources in place and opportunities to develop 

Decent work-life balance for accounting / finance
Solid benefits

Friendly colleagues and tight-knit group
cons:
Lower than market compensation

Understaffed, partially due to the convoluted and slow processing time by HR, also bare bone budgets which restricts ability to bring on staff

Overall a great place for those looking for career stability, but not for the place to stay long term due to legacy organization (everything is bureaucratic)

No perks or any offerings in the kitchen

review_title: Clinicians and staff create atmosphere of trust and uphold commitment to patients and families through daily practice
job_title: in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Committed, highly qualified and professional staff and practitioners, excellent mission and values, challenging environment full of opportunities to learn and improve skills. Rewarding to work with each patient and family, remembering everyone is first and foremost a human being.
cons: Increased move toward streamlining can improve processes but can run risk of overburdening staff in day-to-day and, by extension, staff can lose sight of overarching mission and the actual relationsip with patient and families gets lost in the checklists.

review_title: LPCH offers great care to their patients.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Working at LPCH allows you to interact with a diverse group of patients/parents. It is amazing to see children being so optimistic even if they have serious illnesses.  The nursing staff is great and give excellent care.
cons: There is lack of support from Executive Leadership to middle management and this causes a lot of distrust and animosity throughout the departments.

review_title: Growing Children's Hospital in Bay Area
job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great educational opportunities, great people to work with, good benefits
cons: work life balance difficult if you commute to work,lots of meeting and mandatory trainings, time off policies changing. Lots of cost  cutting measures in place,starting to affect staffing ratios

job_title: Unit Secretary in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Staff is very friendly and supportive. I always hear nurses asking each other if they're ok or need help. They even ask me! Management recognizes the staff often. LPCH is a great place to work!
cons: The only downside is when you work at other units off site, it is more challenging to do the job because even though you're offsite materials still come from the main campus and the delay in receiving things can be 2 hours.

job_title: Planning and Expansion Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Some of the people are nice and very helpful. The organization balance sheet is quite positive. The location is nice.
cons: In general the atmosphere there is very hostile and negative. Leaders don't know how to lead, they're given titles based on diploma not by their leadership capabilities. LPCH is an organization that works in silos and is extremely competitive, but not in a good way.There exists a tremendous lack of respect for staff all the while pushing out an internal campaign about respecting patients and colleagues--so obviously hypocritical.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great pay and retirement benefits (for the most part) great staff. Whenever you need help (HR/payroll, CRONA, etc) everyone is more gab happy to help.
cons: Heavy work load, management can be tricky (depending on the manager, they can be very strict and buy the book or they can have great communication and work with you on several different topics. I wish medical benefits were better.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Many learning opportunities with high acuity patients; hospital's reputation/name
cons: Unsafe work environment; benefits package not as good as other hospitals; nurse to patient ratio needs to be reduced in order to provide safe care to the very acute patients that this hospital takes on.

review_title: Maintain a high-functioning and efficient desk and ward in a hospital environment where safety and privacy are paramount
job_title: Unit Secretary in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Competitive wages and excellent surroundings attract great staff, and prestige of the Stanford brand brings excellent physicians and students in both medical and nursing school programs.
cons: Sub-par employee benefits, mild employee investment, almost impossible to afford to live within a 40 mile radius of the hospital.

job_title: Clinical Nurse I in Stanford, CA
pros: super helpful program but your experience will depend on the unit you're on. there have been experiences on both side of the spectrum.
cons: management of certain units is seriously lacking along with nurse retention. negativity permeates everywhere, it can be extremely frustrating when all you want is a good learning environment.

review_title: Great benefits, great co-workers...a lot of empty promises
job_title: Office Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Benefits and pay are decent (not relative to area however) 

Contributing to the health and wellness of children
cons:
No clear path for promotion regardless of professional enrichment/skill acquisition/past performance

A lot of bureaucracy

job_title: Secretary in San Jose, CA
pros: I enjoyed working with the families and patients.  My co-workers were fantastic as was the management staff.
cons: Had a difficult time adjusting to me medical need (as discovered in fall of 2014) providing me with a headset for telephone use.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: They have a great patient population.
cons: Hard working people did not get rewarded for their hard work in the department I was in. People would get promoted who did not deserve it and vice versa. Very demotivating.

job_title: Unit Secretary in Stanford, CA
pros: Friendly place to work, managers are great. New building is designed well for families.
cons: Location off of the highway takes awhile to get to. As an employee we have to park miles away and take employee shuttles on top of paying for the parking.

review_title: friendly co workers, pretty laid back environment, pay could be a little bit higher
job_title: Authorization Coordinator in Menlo Park, CA
pros: laid back environment..friendly co workers, managers are very approachable.
cons:
some workers take advantage of being in a full time position and doesn't seem to be productive. 
no feedback from managers of how a certain employees performance is.

review_title: Don't expect promotions for hard work
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Stanford, CA
pros: Steady stable employment, lots of educational opportunities.
cons: Management is a joke, they bully employees and will add duties to your workload and allow their favorites to get paid for nothing. Horrible management, unfair and will lie on you to build a case against you.

job_title: Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Great place to work. Great benefits. Wonderful culture. Most people have longevity here. Great mission. The company’s mission is akin to my values
cons: Better salary. Could do more. Would like to make more money, but not sure if there’s a role for me to fill.

job_title: Systems Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great organization.  Innovative, cutting edge medical achievements are pursued consistently, compensation is on par with the rest of the bay area.
cons: Small hospital where people are employed for a significant amount of time, opportunity for growth may be limited by tenor.

job_title: Office Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Lpch is an amazing company to work for. They really look to empower there staff to make a difference in the lives of those they touch.
cons: I don't have any negatives to write about. This has been a great organization to work for.

job_title: Network Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: very satisfying to work for the health of children
cons: Network Managers lacks Network knowledge and information is based on how they can move up the ladder

review_title: Overall a good place to work
job_title: Dietitian in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Co-workers are friendly and nice. Benefits. Always changing.
cons: The health insurance. Construction. Can be overworked

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Palo Alto, CA
pros: They don't fire anyone, even if you can't do the job.
cons: You have to work with incompetent people, and work is usually left upon one capable person per project.

job_title: Lead Financial Analyst in San Mateo, CA
pros: Good work life Balance, competitive pay and great retirement matching funds. Interesting projects and smart people.
cons: Slow to adapt to change as an organization. Multiple rounds of buy-in needed to complete projects

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Ok Pay. Wealthy institution. Association with Stanford. located in Beautiful Palo Alto
cons: Slow to advance with little recognition

job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Great co-workers, management, physicians and nurses
cons: Sometimes the influence of the unions is a positive--sometimes a negative...

job_title: Medical Interpreter and Translator in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Highly skilled coworkers, exciting work, constant learning,
cons: Lots of talk about respect for the profession and the suggestions of employees, but this isn't implemented. The department's hands are somewhat tied.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Good pay.  Good benefits. Food sometimes.
cons: Unprofessional and under staffed. Management doesn't have much experience.

job_title: Improvement Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Stanford has a great name and from a Lean Thinking perspective they are a leading hospital.
cons: Poor executive leadership and middle management

job_title: Performance Improvement Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Incredible people, opportunity to be hands on, small and welcoming community
cons: Slow career growth, complacency, many unnecessary processes that slowed work down on administrative side

job_title: in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Great teamwork. Employees focus on the patient at all times
cons: There are no negatives working for this wonderful organization.

job_title: Clinical Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Shared Governance; the team cares about you as an employee; great pay and benefits
cons: I've had mostly all experiences so far. Nothing bad to report.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great benefits great pay great director Dewain and daphne! They gave me a great opportunity thank you!
cons: The supervisor are no good Trishon I hated

job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Amazing culture, many resources, great benefits
cons: Lack of communication with upper management, runaround for disability, just beginning to support nurses regarding workplace violence

job_title: Clinical Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Amazing Leadership Teams, Management is always communicating with you
cons: Bay Area Commute to the hospital can be tough

job_title: Coding Charge Entry Analyst in Stanford, CA
pros: The benefit packaged is good.
cons: Parking is hard and limited.

job_title: Front Office Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great team values, it's the people that make this place
cons: The manager is not great they love to micro manage the employees

job_title: New Patient Coordinator in Fremont, CA
pros: I love working for stanford
cons: I'm looking for a job with earlier hours or closer to home

job_title: Medical Assistant in Hercules, CA
pros: Great pay. Benefits start right away
cons: Lack of Support from leaders

job_title: Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros: great benefits, including lots of vacation time
cons: Senior management expects a lot of long hours

job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Strong union, great management
cons: Everything based on seniority.

job_title: Assistant Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great benefits, great pay, great people
cons: Communication flow,  politics, pay for parking

job_title: RN, Bsn in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great Process improvement team
cons: Work schedule  could be exhausting and unhealthy.

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits are good. Schedule is ok.
cons: Culture needs to change, poor management

job_title: Office Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: great working enviroment and people
cons: tough to find parking most of the time

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Palo Alto, CA
pros: the union helps keep pay great
cons: old building for labor and delivery

job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: good PTO, good benefits, good retirement plan
cons: overworked, understaffed, poor management support

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner I in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Plenty of overtime, flexible scheduling
cons: Not enough autonomy, can be monotonous
